lkl_dummyResumeText_SUMM_FRFM: Highly organised and disciplined pharmacy leader with excellent communication and conflict resolution skills. Competent in managing supplies, reviewing service quality, and maintaining patient confidentiality and satisfaction. Skilled at ordering, storing, and preparing medications for customer use. Accomplished in increasing customer satisfaction while improving controls, team operations, and loss prevention strategies. Knowledgeable in preparing special compounds.
lkl_dummyResumeText_EXPR_0_JDES:
• Checked more than 30 patient orders against histories each day, assessed insurance coverage and counted out medicines.
  • Provided patient counselling regarding OTC medications.
  • Managed weekly schedules and requests for leave.
lkl_dummyResumeText_EXPR_1_JDES:
• Used pharmacy software Meditab to verify prescription and insurance information.
  • Compounded and prepared medications according to prescription orders for more than 160 prescriptions every week.
  • Solicited medical history information from patients to provide best and most effective medical advice.
lkl_dummyResumeText_EXPR_2_JDES:
• Delivered an exceptional level of service to each customer by listening to concerns and answering questions.
  • Communicated with nursing and medical personnel regarding medication orders or drug therapy issues.
  • Instructed individuals on proper use of blood pressure monitors and other medical devices.
  • Filled as many as 160 prescriptions every week.
lkl_dummyResumeText_CUST_FRFM:
• Running marathons
  • read specialist literature
  • win business for customers
lkl_definition_tips_17_tips:
• A1 Beginner: can understand simple phrases and ask basic questions.
  • A2 Elementary: can have short conversations and provide routine information.
  • B1 Intermediate: can have slightly more complex conversations and communicate in past and future tenses.
  • B2 Upper-intermediate: can communicate confidently in most professional or academic settings.
  • C1 Advanced: has a strong command of the language and can read and discuss complex material.
  • C2 Proficient: can communicate with the skill and ease of a native speaker.
additionalsectionTipSubTitle: Let's consider other sections to enhance your CV
lkl_Definition_Tips_SUMM_tips:
• Your CV summary should hook in the reader instantly.
  • Provide the employer with a clear snapshot of who you are, what you have to offer, and what you would like to accomplish.
  • Begin with your most marketable attribute. For example, 'seasoned administrative assistant' or 'certified master carpenter'.
  • Remember to keep your summary a concise 3-4 sentences.
lkl_Definition_Tips_SUMM_studentTips:
• Your CV summary should hook in the reader instantly.
  • Provide the employer with a clear snapshot of who you are, what you have to offer, and what you can accomplish.
  • If youâ€™re new to the workforce, highlight qualities and skills you gained in school or through life experiences that match the job description.
  • Begin with your most marketable attribute. For example, 'seasoned administrative assistant' or 'certified master carpenter'
  • Remember to keep your summary a concise 3-4 sentences.
    • .
lkl_Definition_Tips_SUMM_defaultText: Choose a recommended summary example below.
lkl_Definition_Tips_SUMM_definition: An overview of your career stating your most important strengths and abilities. This section provides a clear snapshot of who you are, what you can offer and what you would like to accomplish.
lkl_Definition_Tips_HILT_tips:
• When applying for a new position, it is recommended to add 4-8 skills relevant to the target job.
  • Mix in technical skills that highlight your knowledge of tools, such as Microsoft Office, and soft skills that will help you succeed, such as team player and leadership skills.
  • If youâ€™re unsure what to add to your CV, review the job description to see what the employer is looking for.
  • A good approach is to focus on those skills and include the top keywords.
lkl_Definition_Tips_HILT_studentTips:
• When applying for a new position, it is recommended to add 4-8 skills relevant to the target job.
  • Mix in technical skills that highlight your knowledge of tools, such as Microsoft Office, and soft skills that will help you succeed, such as team player and leadership skills.
  • If youâ€™re unsure what to add to your CV, review the job description to see what the employer is looking for.
  • A good approach is to focus on those skills and include the top keywords.
lkl_Definition_Tips_HILT_definition: In this two-column section, use bullet points to highlight your top 4-8 skills. We recommend listing skills in short, 1-2 words, without punctuation.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EXPR_tips:
• Include up to 10 years of recent work history, beginning with your current or most recent employer.
  • Use bullet points to list your major accomplishments and experience so that employers can scan your CV easily.
  • If you are applying for a job where you have no experience, showcase skills and experience that will be valuable in your new job.
  • If you have relevant work history from more than 10 years ago, we recommend adding a separate section called Additional Work History.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EXPR_defaultText: Describe what you did in this position. Type your bullet points here or choose from the recommended phrases below.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EDUC_tips:
• Before you write your education section, read the job description to find out which degrees or certifications are required.
  • If you have earned a university degree, you do not need to include your General Certificate of Secondary Education (GCSE) or A-Levels on your CV.
  • Your most recent degree should be the first entry in your education section.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EDUC_studentTips:
• Before you start your education section, read the job description to see which qualifications are needed, such as degrees, certifications, and licences.
  • Your most recent and relevant qualification should be the first entry in your education section.
  • If you are currently pursuing a degree, don't forget to add your projected completion date in the year of graduation field.
  • If you have no work history, consider putting this section above Work History on the Finalise page by moving sections around.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EDUC_definition: Any degrees, coursework, professional development or training programmes that you have completed in preparation for your target job.
lkl_Definition_Tips_AFIL_defaultText: Type in your activities and honours.
lkl_Definition_Tips_ACCM_tips:
• Employers look for accomplishments in the workplace and outside the workplace, such as raising $500 for a charity.
  • Carefully choose your accomplishments to make your CV stand out in a pool of candidates applying for the same job.
  • Add "the what" and "why" to quantify what you achieved using numbers whenever possible.
lkl_Definition_Tips_CERT_tips:
• Some employers require certifications to ensure that you have sufficient work history for the target job.
  • Other employers use certifications to verify your experience level, additional skills, or practical experience.
  • Review the job description to see which certification is required, or add a certificate to showcase your unique skills.
lkl_Definition_Tips_TSKL_tips: Add any technical skills, including, but not limited to, computer skills.
lkl_Definition_Tips_TSKL_definition: Any technical skills, including, but not limited to, computer skills.
lkl_Definition_Tips_TSKL_defaultText: List specific technical skills that employers may want to see, such as specific software, tools and programming languages.
lkl_Definition_Tips_ESUM_tips: This section is a summary paragraph consisting of 3-4 sentences focusing on the highlights of your career and your abilities.
lkl_Definition_Tips_ESUM_definition: A summary paragraph consisting of 3-4 sentences focusing on the highlights of your career and your abilities.
lkl_Definition_Tips_ESUM_defaultText: Enter a brief description of your professional background. You can choose to highlight specific skills, knowledge or industry experience.
lkl_Definition_Tips_ESUM_defaultTextESUM: Enter 4-6 areas of expertise that you'd like to feature.
lkl_Definition_Tips_EEXP_tips:
• List measurable, results-focused accomplishments, such as saving money or increasing productivity for your employer by a certain amount or percentage; be specific.
  • Showcase how your leadership impacted the employer for the better.
  • Include the number of employees at each employer that reported to you.
lkl_Definition_Tips_MILI_tips:
• Translate military terms and job positions into language and job titles a civilian employer can understand.
  • You may choose to list awards or medals -- or mention the fact that you received such honours. If you received an honourable discharge, you may include this information, or leave it out.
  • Don't divulge confidential information about specific military missions.
  • Focus on relevant transferable skills. Also emphasise dedication, sense of responsibility or other qualities that you honed during your years of service.
  • Leave out details of active combat -- this kind of experience doesn't translate well to most civilian jobs.
  • Spell out acronyms and explain the significance of achievements that may not be clear to civilians.
  • Include position, department and years served in the armed forces.
lkl_Definition_Tips_MILI_defaultText: Describe your service in the military here, focusing on experience that will transfer to your target job.
lkl_Definition_Tips_MILI_definition: Your military experience is a great asset. Most employers value veterans for their skills and service. Ideally you should include transferable skills from your military experience throughout your CV, and also highlight additional achievement.
lkl_Definition_Tips_LNGG_tips:
• A1 Beginner: can understand simple phrases and ask basic questions.
  • A2 Elementary: can have short conversations and provide routine information.
  • B1 Intermediate: can have slightly more complex conversations and communicate in past and future tenses.
  • B2 Upper-intermediate: can communicate confidently in most professional or academic settings.
  • C1 Advanced: has a strong command of the language and can read and discuss complex material.
  • C2 Proficient: can communicate with the skill and ease of a native speaker.

advertisingDescription: Third parties place advertising cookies in order to measure and send you content based on your preferences. These cookies will allow you to interact better with their third-party platforms.
necessaryDescription: Essential cookies are needed in order for the Site to function properly and be able to provide you with our services. Therefore, essential cookies will always be dropped and cannot be refused. For example, these cookies allow us to apply security settings, know if a user is signed in, create document ids, track if a document has been printed or downloaded, and store the userâ€™s information.
policyDetailText: In order to provide a better experience while creating your CV versions and cover letters, we may use cookies as part of the Site. For the same purpose, we may share the information gathered with third parties. If you would like to have more details about the use of cookies, please visit our Cookie Policy. Set your cookie preferences by clicking Cookie settings or you can accept all cookies by clicking "Accept all".
cookieDetails: A detailed list of cookies can be seen here
